Complexity of Deciding Detectability in Discrete Event Systems

TomÃ¡Å¡Â Masopust masopust@math.cas.cz Institute of Mathematics, Czech Academy of Sciences, Å½iÅ¾kova 22, 616 62 Brno, Czechia
Abstract

Detectability of discrete event systems (DESs) is a question whether the current and subsequent states can be determined based on observations. Shu and Lin designed a polynomial-time algorithm to check strong (periodic) detectability and an exponential-time (polynomial-space) algorithm to check weak (periodic) detectability. Zhang showed that checking weak (periodic) detectability is PSpace-complete. This intractable complexity opens a question whether there are structurally simpler DESs for which the problem is tractable. In this paper, we show that it is not the case by considering DESs represented as deterministic finite automata without non-trivial cycles, which are structurally the simplest deadlock-free DESs. We show that even for such very simple DESs, checking weak (periodic) detectability remains intractable. On the contrary, we show that strong (periodic) detectability of DESs can be efficiently verified on a parallel computer.

keywords:
Discrete event systems; Finite automata; Detectability

1 Introduction

The detectability problem of discrete event systems (DESs) is a question whether the current and subsequent states of a DES can be determined based on observations. The problem was introduced and studied by Shu et al.Â [11, 13]. Detectability generalizes other notions studied in the literatureÂ [3, 10], such as stability of Ozveren and WillskyÂ [9]. Shu et al. further argue that many practical problems can be formulated as the detectability problem for DESs.

Four variants of detectability have been defined: strong and weak detectability and strong and weak periodic detectabilityÂ [13]. Shu et al.Â [13] investigated detectability for deterministic DESs. A deterministic DES is modeled as a deterministic finite automaton with a set of initial states rather than a single initial state. The motivation for more initial states comes from the observation that it is often not known which state the system is initially in. They designed exponential algorithms to decide detectability of DESs based on the computation of the observer. Later, to be able to handle more problems, they extended their study to nondeterministic DESs and improved the algorithms for strong (periodic) detectability of nondeterministic DESs to polynomial timeÂ [11]. Concerning the complexity of deciding weak detectability, ZhangÂ [16] showed that the problem is PSpace-complete and that PSpace-hardness holds even for deterministic DESs with all events observable. Shu and LinÂ [12] further extended strong detectability to delayed DESs and developed a polynomial-time algorithm to check strong detectability for delayed DESs. Yin and LafortuneÂ [15] recently extended weak and strong detectability to modular DESs and showed that checking both strong modular detectability and weak modular detectability is PSpace-hard.

Zhangâ€™s intractable complexity of deciding weak (periodic) detectability opens the question whether there are structurally simpler DESs for which tractability can be achieved. To tackle this question, we consider structurally the simplest deadlock-free DESs modeled as deterministic finite automata without non-trivial cycles, that is, every cycle is in the form of a self-loop in a state of the DES. We show that even for these very simple DESs, checking weak (periodic) detectability remains PSpace-complete, and hence the problem is intractable for all practical cases.

On the other hand, we show that deciding strong (periodic) detectability of DESs is NL-complete. Since NL is the class of problems that can be efficiently parallelizedÂ [1], we obtain that strong (periodic) detectability can be efficiently verified on a parallel computer.

A decision problem is a yes-no question, such as â€œIs an NFA Ağ´A deterministic?â€ A decision problem is decidable if there exists an algorithm solving the problem. Complexity theory classifies decidable problems to classes based on the time or space an algorithm needs to solve the problem. The complexity classes we consider in this paper are NL, P, NP, and PSpace denoting the classes of problems solvable by a nondeterministic logarithmic-space, deterministic polynomial-time, nondeterministic polynomial-time, and deterministic polynomial-space algorithm, respectively. The hierarchy of classes is NL âŠ†\subseteq P âŠ†\subseteq NP âŠ†\subseteq PSpace. Which of the inclusions are strict is an open problem. The widely accepted conjecture is that all are strict. A decision problem is NL-complete (resp. NP-complete, PSpace-complete) if it belongs to NL (resp. NP, PSpace) and every problem from NL (resp. NP, PSpace) can be reduced to it by a deterministic logarithmic-space (resp. polynomial-time) algorithm.

4 Complexity of Deciding Weak Detectability

To decide weak (periodic) detectability of a DES, Shu and LinÂ [11] construct the observer and prove that the DES is weakly detectable if and only if there is a reachable cycle in the observer consisting of singleton DES state sets, and that the DES is weakly periodically detectable if and only if there is a reachable cycle in the observer containing a singleton DES state set. Because of the construction of the observer, the algorithms are exponential. However, as pointed out by ZhangÂ [16], the algorithms require only polynomial space.

ZhangÂ [16] further shows that deciding weak (periodic) detectability is PSpace-hard. His construction results in a deterministic DES with several initial states. Although the transitions are deterministic, the DES is not a DFA because of the non-unique initial state. We slightly improve Zhangâ€™s result.

Deciding whether a deterministic DES over a binary alphabet is weakly (periodically) detectable is PSpace-complete.

Corollary 7.

Deciding whether a DES modeled as a DFA is weakly (periodically) detectable is PSpace-complete even if the DES has only three events, one of which is unobservable.

Proof 4.2.

Consider the deterministic DES GğºG constructed in the proof of TheoremÂ 6 with n+1ğ‘›1n+1 initial states denoted by q1,â€¦,qn+1subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›1q_{1},\ldots,q_{n+1}. We construct Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} from GğºG by adding a new unobservable event ağ‘a, the transitions (qi,a,qi+1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1(q_{i},a,q_{i+1}), for i=1,â€¦,nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i=1,\ldots,n, and by setting q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1} to be the sole initial state of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}. All other transitions of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} coincide with those of GğºG. Then Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is a DFA and it is easy to see that the observers of GğºG with respect to âˆ…\emptyset and of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} with respect to {a}ğ‘\{a\} are identical, and hence GğºG is weakly (periodically) detectable if and only if Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} is.

The unobservable event in the corollary is unavoidable because any DES modeled as a DFA with all events observable is always in a unique state, and hence trivially detectable. We now show that two observable events are also necessary for PSpace-hardness.

Theorem 8.

Deciding whether a DES over a unary alphabet is weakly detectable is in P, and whether it is weakly periodically detectable is in NP.

Proof 4.3.

Let G=(Q,{a},Î´,I)ğºğ‘„ğ‘ğ›¿ğ¼G=(Q,\{a\},\delta,I) be a DES with nğ‘›n states. 4.1 Simplest DESs

Zhangâ€™s result gives rise to a question whether there are structurally simpler DESs with a tractable complexity of weak (periodic) detectability. The simplest DESs are acyclic DFAs, recognizing finite languages. Acyclic DESs are not deadlock-free. To fulfill deadlock-freeness, we consider DESs modeled as DFAs with cycles only in the form of self-loops. Such DFAs recognize a strict subclass of regular languages strictly included in star-free languagesÂ [2]. Star-free languages are languages definable by linear temporal logic widely used as a specification language in automated verification.

Let A=(Q,Î£,Î´,I,F)ğ´ğ‘„Î£ğ›¿ğ¼ğ¹A=(Q,\Sigma,\delta,I,F) be an NFA. The reachability relation â‰¤\leq on the state set Qğ‘„Q is defined by pâ‰¤qğ‘ğ‘p\leq q if there is wâˆˆÎ£âˆ—ğ‘¤superscriptÎ£w\in\Sigma^{*} such that qâˆˆÎ´â€‹(p,w)ğ‘ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘¤q\in\delta(p,w). The NFA Ağ´A is partially ordered (poNFA) if the reachability relation â‰¤\leq is a partial order. If Ağ´A is a DFA, we use the notation poDFA.

A restricted partially ordered NFA (rpoNFA) is a poNFA that is self-loop deterministic in the sense that the pattern of Fig.Â 2 does not appear. Formally, for every state qğ‘q and every event ağ‘a, if qâˆˆÎ´â€‹(q,a)ğ‘ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘q\in\delta(q,a) then Î´â€‹(q,a)={q}ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\delta(q,a)=\{q\}.

This condition is trivially satisfied by poDFAs and it is known that poDFAs and rpoNFAs recognize the same class of languagesÂ [7].

We show that deciding weak (periodic) detectability remains PSpace-complete even if the DES is modeled as a poDFA, or as an rpoNFA with all events observable. Consequently, the problem is intractable for all practical cases.

Recall that ZhangÂ [16] obtained his result by reducing the finite automata intersection problem. Since his construction does not introduce any non-trivial cycles, it could seem that it also shows the result for poDFAs. This is, however, not the case because the complexity of the intersection problem for poDFAs is not known. Therefore, to prove our results, we need to use a different technique, namely the universality problem for rpoNFAs. The problem asks, given an rpoNFA Ağ´A over Î£Î£\Sigma, whether Lâ€‹(A)=Î£âˆ—ğ¿ğ´superscriptÎ£L(A)=\Sigma^{*}. It is PSpace-complete in general and coNP-complete if the alphabet is fixed a prioriÂ [7].

5 Complexity of Deciding Strong Detectability

Shu and LinÂ [11] designed a polynomial-time algorithm to decide strong (periodic) detectability, and hence the problem is in P. Is the problem P-complete or does it belong to NL? This question asks whether the problem can be efficiently parallelized (is in NL) or not (is P-complete)Â [1]. We show that the problem is NL-complete and can thus be efficiently solved on a parallel computer.

Theorem 11.

Deciding whether a DES is strongly (periodically) detectable is NL-complete.

Proof 5.1.

For a DES GğºG, Shu and LinÂ [11] construct an NFA Gdâ€‹eâ€‹tsubscriptğºğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡G_{det} of polynomial size whose states are subsets of states of GğºG of cardinality one or two (except for the initial state), such that GğºG is strongly detectable if and only if (a) any state reachable from any loop in Gdâ€‹eâ€‹tsubscriptğºğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡G_{det} is of cardinality one; and strongly periodically detectable if and only if (b) all loops in Gdâ€‹eâ€‹tsubscriptğºğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡G_{det} include at least one state of cardinality one.

We prove the membership in NL by showing that checking that the conditions do not hold is in NL. Since NL is closed under complementÂ [5, 14], checking that the conditions are satisfied is also in NL.

To check that (a) is not satisfied, the NL algorithm guesses two states of Gdâ€‹eâ€‹tsubscriptğºğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡G_{det}, xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y, where yğ‘¦y is of cardinality two, and verifies that yğ‘¦y is reachable from xğ‘¥x, xğ‘¥x is reachable from the initial state of Gdâ€‹eâ€‹tsubscriptğºğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡G_{det}, and xğ‘¥x is in a cycle, i.e., xğ‘¥x is reachable from xğ‘¥x by a path having at least one transition.

To check that (b) is not satisfied, the NL algorithm guesses a state xğ‘¥x of Gdâ€‹eâ€‹tsubscriptğºğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡G_{det} of cardinality two and verifies that xğ‘¥x is reachable from the initial state of Gdâ€‹eâ€‹tsubscriptğºğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡G_{det} and that xğ‘¥x is in a cycle consisting only of states of cardinality two.

For more details how to check reachability in NL, the reader is referred to the literatureÂ [8].

To show NL-hardness, we reduce the DAG non-reachability problemÂ [4]. Given a directed acyclic graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) and nodes s,tâˆˆVğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‰s,t\in V, it asks whether tğ‘¡t is not reachable from sğ‘ s.

From GğºG, we construct a DES A=(Vâˆª{â™£},{a},Î´,s)ğ´ğ‘‰â™£ğ‘ğ›¿ğ‘ A=(V\cup\{\clubsuit\},\{a\},\delta,s), where â™£âˆ‰Vâ™£ğ‘‰\clubsuit\notin V is a new state and ağ‘a is an observable event. For every (p,r)âˆˆEğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ¸(p,r)\in E, we add the transition (p,a,r)ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ(p,a,r) to Î´ğ›¿\delta, and for every pâˆˆVâˆ–{t}ğ‘ğ‘‰ğ‘¡p\in V\setminus\{t\}, we add the transition (p,a,â™£)ğ‘ğ‘â™£(p,a,\clubsuit) to Î´ğ›¿\delta. Moreover, we add the self-loop transitions (â™£,a,â™£)â™£ğ‘â™£(\clubsuit,a,\clubsuit) and (t,a,t)ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¡(t,a,t) to Î´ğ›¿\delta. The construction is depicted in Fig.Â 8. Notice that Ağ´A is deadlock-free and has no unobservable events. We now show that tğ‘¡t is not reachable from sğ‘ s in the graph GğºG if and only if the DES Ağ´A is strongly (periodically) detectable.

If node tğ‘¡t is not reachable from sğ‘ s in GğºG, then, for every kâ‰¥|V|ğ‘˜ğ‘‰k\geq|V|, Î´â€‹(s,ak)={â™£}ğ›¿ğ‘ superscriptğ‘ğ‘˜â™£\delta(s,a^{k})=\{\clubsuit\}. Hence Ağ´A is strongly (periodically) detectable.

If tğ‘¡t is reachable from sğ‘ s, then, for every kâ‰¥|V|ğ‘˜ğ‘‰k\geq|V|, Î´â€‹(s,ak)={t,â™£}ğ›¿ğ‘ superscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¡â™£\delta(s,a^{k})=\{t,\clubsuit\}. Hence Ağ´A is not strongly (periodically) detectable.

We point out that using a unique event for every transition can show NL-hardness for DESs modeled as DFAs.

6 Conclusions

We studied the complexity of deciding detectability of discrete event systems modeled as finite automata and showed that deciding weak (periodic) detectability is intractable for all deadlock-free DESs. On the other hand, we showed that strong (periodic) detectability can be decided efficiently on a parallel computer.
